Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 07:49AM wabiwoman wrote: Wow Deborah, Your generosity abounds -- thanks for filling us RAD girls in on this.  I'm going to print out a copy of your email and the article and bring it to my doc when I have my pre-op prior to my exchange in January. You rock! Geena
Posts.Title: Fat Graft Transfer and the Radiated Breast whippetmom dancetrancer

Posts.Content: May 22, 2009 05:51PM wabiwoman wrote: Lursa, I'm wondering how you're doing.  I just came across this thread and I am so impressed by your honesty.  I actually work as a clinical social worker and counsel a number of Suboxone clients - most had been addicted to pain meds.  I'm due to have a bilat mast and reconstruction next week and I was blown away when my PS gave me a prescrip for 90 heavy duty meds to fill prior to my surgery - no questions asked.  Never once have I ever been asked by a medical provider if I've ever struggled with addiction and I find that to be a real failing of the industry.  Anyway, I really hope you check back and let us know how you're faring!!! Peace, Geena
Posts.Title: To tell or not. Need Advice Lursa5 nancypat

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 04:17PM - edited Aug 30, 2010 08:28AM by wabiwoman Lindainfl, I am soooo glad you wrote about this and asked this.  I have had reconstruction after a bilateral mastectomy, and the results haven't been so aesthetically pleasing.  I've been considering taking my implants out for a while, but I know the rub for me is about dating, or more specifically, sex.  I don't really care about having "form" in my clothes.  I recconstructed because I was concerned about finding a potential partner and being intimate.  At 47 and never having been married if I listen to society my "chances" of finding a decent partner are labelled as "slim".  I was afraid of turning "slim" into "zilch" if I chose not to reconstruct.  I say all this as someone who speaks to others (as a profession) about living with positivity, letting go of negative thinking, having faith, doing the best we can, letting go of the outcome of the path, being confident -- and yet in my smaller mind I get scared and don't believe this.  I can easily fear, unfortunately.   So now I have these reconstructed things, no nipples, no aereola, lots of rippling and one breast that seems to want to make its way towards my armpit, I'm wondering if it is indeed any better than having no reconstruction.  I am unconvinced.  I know when I had a BRCA test the genetics counselor said she had clients who chose no reconstruction and they continued to date, be in marriages, etc.  I may indeed follow the path you have chosen after all. I do think it is indeed an issue of faith, doing what we can to make things happen (the footwork), having confidence and being self loving.  This is "thinking".  My emotions need to now step up to the plate!!! Geena
Posts.Title: dating lindainfla lindainfla

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 02:04PM wabiwoman wrote: Thank you, thank you, thank you to all you fabulous women!  I am 6 weeks post bilateral mastectomy with tissue expander placement - that is not going too well.  Side that had been previously radiated just not healing and I'm back to the OR on Tuesday to deflate, get bad skin cut off and re-sew.  My PS KNOWs I won't do too much of this - and I won't do a tissue flap.... SOOO I've been wondering a lot about the flat look, how that would be.... these pics are a GIFT for someone like me.... you all look beautiful!

Posts.Title: I LIVE ALONE - post bi lat mast help? wabiwoman Jeansbeans

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 05:12AM wabiwoman wrote: Oh Gosh!  I just checked in to my "Favorite Topics" and saw that I had not kept up!  Let me update you dear women!  My surgery was scheduled for April 23, but my surgeon's husband passed away suddenly and all of her surgeries had to be rescheduled with other surgeons.  My surgery will now be on May 27th - and I am eager to have it done.  It has been a TRIP organizing help, and honestly, finally put a good friend on the task when I hit "overwhelm".  I am blessed with lovely friends who are all pitching in with this and that - including a small team to clean my apartment the day before I go into the hospital!  Score!  :)  No, really, I feel really fortunate.  The tips I've gained from this thread helped me figure out what I needed to get/do - helped focus me - and be very efficient about asking for the help that I would clearly need (those first few days....).  Fingers crossed for the 27th, and thank you so very much for all the wisdom shared with me here! Geena in Providence
Posts.Title: I LIVE ALONE - post bi lat mast help? wabiwoman Jeansbeans

Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 02:03PM wabiwoman wrote: Hi all, Thanks for all the wonderful advice.  I've been trying to just "live my life" before surgery and not obsess about what is upcoming, but now that my surgery date is close I have to attend....  I've got my team of friends in place and now it's just about prepping some food, putting things at waist level.  My only concern is about my bed set up.  I really don't want to spend money on this cancer thing if I can help it.  I'm not going to rent a recliner - I have strong abdominals - I'm thinking maybe if I just get some extra pillows to prop me up a bit in bed - I'll be OK.  Hope that's true!!  I guess if it's not I'll get someone to roll up blankets, etc.  I have to let go and trust I'll be taken care of....  some part of me believes if I'm not on top of everything it'll all fall apart.  Letting go, letting go, letting go......  Thank you for all the warm and supportive thoughts!!!! Hugs back, Geena
Posts.Title: I LIVE ALONE - post bi lat mast help? wabiwoman Jeansbeans

Posts.Title: Hints on Preparation for Recovery Time? wabiwoman wabiwoman

Posts.Content: wabiwoman wrote: Hi all, I'll be having a bilateral mastectomy and reconstruction expanders inserted in 2.5 weeks.  I live alone (with two fabulous felines) and I need some hints on what I should definitely have on hand to make recovery time easier.  I know I need to lower things so I'm not reaching up, need to have some meals prepared, I'm guessing I need my clothes to be button based and not put on over my head, need to have friends and family on hand to help for - what - a week?  I know it's only people who have been through these things who really have the lowdow on what I should do/have around to be ready (as ready as one can be...) for this.  Any special hints?  Thanks sooooo very much! Geena in Providence, RI Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 05:23AM wabiwoman wrote: Wow.  Thanks so much everyone for the advice.  Seems I should have someone immediately about for a couple of days.  The more info I get, the better I feel.  I may not be able to control this cancer situation, but I can certainly take charge of how it plays out logistically.  I truly appreciate all the generous sharing of experience and tips.  Peace, Geena in Providence
